timeline.bodyText:
we need to think on what approach for exception validation is better for us
https://www.baeldung.com/junit-assert-exception
usage is Rule is good, junit5 approach also looks interesting but still creates nesting blocks.
@strkkk , @rnveach , @nmancus1 , what is more preferable way of exception validation for you.
timeline.author: romani

replies.bodyText: Sounds good. I'll try to use assertThrows + Truth.
replies.author: pbludov

replies.bodyText: assertThrows looks like a better way to me
replies.author: strkkk

replies.bodyText:
I would prefer https://assertj.github.io/doc/ over either JUnit4 or JUnit5 exception validation (read more at https://www.baeldung.com/introduction-to-assertj), but I am not sure if this is an option that we could use. In my opinion, it is the most readable(by far) of the three.
Out of the two options given above @Rule (JUnit4) and assertThrows (JUnit5), I think that @Rule is more readable. However, JUnit5 is overall a better UT framework, since we can import only the modules we need, and can run tests in parallel.
I would rank the three options as follows:

assertJ
JUnit5 assertThrows
JUnit4 @Rule
replies.author: nmancus1
